content: quote: Originally posted by Irwin_R_Schyster: IRS...I despise tax and spend politics, but he was also a wrestler.. As opposed to "borrow and spend" politics? Like it or not, Bush left this country in a real craphole of a mess, and it's going to take a lot of work to get us out of it. Cuss as you may about Obama's stimulus package - but at this point it's likely the only thing that's kept us from becoming a third world economy. As to the tax side of it, I'd rather pay for it now than leave it as a burden for our kids and grandkids to pay off.

content: There is good reason to suspect that Ms Sotomayor is racist. Look at the quote in question again. She said... "I would hope that a wise Latina woman with the richness of her experience would more often than not reach a better conclusion than a white male who hasn't lived that life." Now let's give it what I call the "white man" test. If you have a white male makeing a similar statement and it isn't racist, well, she's OK. Fair enough? I would hope that a white man man with the richness of his experience would more often than not reach a better conclusion than a [enter minority here] who hasn't lived that life." There is nothing about being Hispanic and/or female that disqualifies anyone from the court. But their beliefs certainly could. Did Lincoln "snuff out" the Southern white GOP vote "for good?"

content: quote: Originally posted by Yooper_tj: quote: Originally posted by scooter_mech: There is good reason to suspect that Ms Sotomayor is racist. Look at the quote in question again. She said... "I would hope that a wise Latina woman with the richness of her experience would more often than not reach a better conclusion than a white male who hasn't lived that life." Now let's give it what I call the "white man" test. If you have a white male makeing a similar statement and it isn't racist, well, she's OK. Fair enough? I would hope that a white man man with the richness of his experience would more often than not reach a better conclusion than a [enter minority here] who hasn't lived that life." There is nothing about being Hispanic and/or female that disqualifies anyone from the court. But their beliefs certainly could. Did Lincoln "snuff out" the Southern white GOP vote "for good?" Perhaps not, but the backlash in the South during the last two congressional elections (and of course in putting a Dem in the White House) will render the rantings about activism and 'beliefs' to be only so much blather. The Big Fat Liar in Chief said it during the Alito confirmation process--win an election or STFU. Knock the process all you want, but the GOP pizzed off enough Americans this past 6 years that they have pretty well shut themselves out of any opportunity to even obstruct any Obama judicial appointment. From the level of discourse I see lately, get used to it. title: Has the GOP Snuffed the Hispanic Vote for Good?

content: quote: Originally posted by Azurerepublic: You can only kiss the hispanic vote good bye if all hispanics are the same. But the racist hispanic vote, yeah, the GOP might be losing that vote. No one is saying that all Hispanics are the same. What some of us are simply saying is the GOP is losing Hispanic support which translates into votes. We saw that in the 2006 and 2008 elections. If those trends continue, and there is no reason to think that they won't, more Hispanics will be voting Democratic. I wouldn't go so far as to say that the GOP has lost 99% of the Hispanic vote, but that party has certainly lost over 50% of the Hispanic vote. When the GOP hate mongers such as Limbaugh and his likes make RACIST statements on radio/internet, constantly bashing President Obama, and Judge Sotomayer, it's not just Democrats who take notice of the negativism that is spewed. No one starts a war--or rather, no one in his senses ought to do so--without first being clear in his mind what he intends to achieve by that war and how he intends to conduct it. Carl von Clausewitz
quote: Originally posted by Azurerepublic: You can only kiss the hispanic vote good bye if all hispanics are the same. But the racist hispanic vote, yeah, the GOP might be losing that vote.
reply: No one is saying that all Hispanics are the same. What some of us are simply saying is the GOP is losing Hispanic support which translates into votes. We saw that in the 2006 and 2008 elections. If those trends continue, and there is no reason to think that they won't, more Hispanics will be voting Democratic. I wouldn't go so far as to say that the GOP has lost 99% of the Hispanic vote, but that party has certainly lost over 50% of the Hispanic vote. When the GOP hate mongers such as Limbaugh and his likes make RACIST statements on radio/internet, constantly bashing President Obama, and Judge Sotomayer, it's not just Democrats who take notice of the negativism that is spewed. No one starts a war--or rather, no one in his senses ought to do so--without first being clear in his mind what he intends to achieve by that war and how he intends to conduct it. Carl von Clausewitz

content: quote: Originally posted by Yooper_tj: quote: Originally posted by ProgMod: quote: Originally posted by Azurerepublic: You can only kiss the hispanic vote good bye if all hispanics are the same. But the racist hispanic vote, yeah, the GOP might be losing that vote. No one is saying that all Hispanics are the same. What some of us are simply saying is the GOP is losing Hispanic support which translates into votes. We saw that in the 2006 and 2008 elections. If those trends continue, and there is no reason to think that they won't, more Hispanics will be voting Democratic. I wouldn't go so far as to say that the GOP has lost 99% of the Hispanic vote, but that party has certainly lost over 50% of the Hispanic vote. When the GOP hate mongers such as Limbaugh and his likes make RACIST statements on radio/internet, constantly bashing President Obama, and Judge Sotomayer, it's not just Democrats who take notice of the negativism that is spewed. ...and if this is truly a center-right country, that observation explains a great deal about the results of the last two congressional elections. Funny how the conservative purists ignore the most important equation I can imagine to their bottom line: Number of Conservative/Repubs in Congress minus the number of Liberal/Dems in Congress equals the net effect on the personal wealth of said conservative. More dems than repubs provides a negative solution to this equation. Shunning impure voters simply makes the negative larger in the next election. I always knew those guys weren't that good at math. Well, Conservative Purists are ignoring A LOT OF THINGS these days....... IMHO, they will simply continue this trend. Tea parties with crumpets and signs displaying Mr. Obama as a nazi or communist will not help their cause, indeed, it will only exacerbate GOP ills. This is especially true when Tom Tancredo and his kind, use the KKK analogy. I see absolutely no reason for repubs to slow or stop these tactics, when especially their red neck base not only applauds them, but like wild animals in the Roman Colosseum, they shout for more, and more, and more. No one starts a war--or rather, no one in his senses ought to do so--without first being clear in his mind what he intends to achieve by that war and how he intends to conduct it. Carl von Clausewitz

What some of us are simply saying is the GOP is losing Hispanic support which translates into votes. We saw that in the 2006 and 2008 elections. If those trends continue, and there is no reason to think that they won't, more Hispanics will be voting Democratic. I wouldn't go so far as to say that the GOP has lost 99% of the Hispanic vote, but that party has certainly lost over 50% of the Hispanic vote. When the GOP hate mongers such as Limbaugh and his likes make RACIST statements on radio/internet, constantly bashing President Obama, and Judge Sotomayer, it's not just Democrats who take notice of the negativism that is spewed. ...and if this is truly a center-right country, that observation explains a great deal about the results of the last two congressional elections. Funny how the conservative purists ignore the most important equation I can imagine to their bottom line: Number of Conservative/Repubs in Congress minus the number of Liberal/Dems in Congress equals the net effect on the personal wealth of said conservative. More dems than repubs provides a negative solution to this equation. Shunning impure voters simply makes the negative larger in the next election. I always knew those guys weren't that good at math.

This is especially true when Tom Tancredo and his kind, use the KKK analogy. I see absolutely no reason for repubs to slow or stop these tactics, when especially their red neck base not only applauds them, but like wild animals in the Roman Colosseum, they shout for more, and more, and more. content: quote: Originally posted by Irwin_R_Schyster: IRS...I despise tax and spend politics, but he was also a wrestler.. As opposed to "borrow and spend" politics? Like it or not, Bush left this country in a real craphole of a mess, and it's going to take a lot of work to get us out of it. Cuss as you may about Obama's stimulus package - but at this point it's likely the only thing that's kept us from becoming a third world economy. As to the tax side of it, I'd rather pay for it now than leave it as a burden for our kids and grandkids to pay off.
quote: Originally posted by Irwin_R_Schyster: IRS...I despise tax and spend politics, but he was also a wrestler..

Cuss as you may about Obama's stimulus package - but at this point it's likely the only thing that's kept us from becoming a third world economy. content: There is good reason to suspect that Ms Sotomayor is racist. Look at the quote in question again. She said... "I would hope that a wise Latina woman with the richness of her experience would more often than not reach a better conclusion than a white male who hasn't lived that life." Now let's give it what I call the "white man" test. If you have a white male makeing a similar statement and it isn't racist, well, she's OK. Fair enough? I would hope that a white man man with the richness of his experience would more often than not reach a better conclusion than a [enter minority here] who hasn't lived that life." There is nothing about being Hispanic and/or female that disqualifies anyone from the court. But their beliefs certainly could. Did Lincoln "snuff out" the Southern white GOP vote "for good?"
reply: There is good reason to suspect that Ms Sotomayor is racist. Look at the quote in question again. She said... content: quote: Originally posted by Yooper_tj: quote: Originally posted by scooter_mech: There is good reason to suspect that Ms Sotomayor is racist. Look at the quote in question again. She said... "I would hope that a wise Latina woman with the richness of her experience would more often than not reach a better conclusion than a white male who hasn't lived that life." Now let's give it what I call the "white man" test. If you have a white male makeing a similar statement and it isn't racist, well, she's OK. Fair enough? I would hope that a white man man with the richness of his experience would more often than not reach a better conclusion than a [enter minority here] who hasn't lived that life." There is nothing about being Hispanic and/or female that disqualifies anyone from the court. But their beliefs certainly could. Did Lincoln "snuff out" the Southern white GOP vote "for good?" Perhaps not, but the backlash in the South during the last two congressional elections (and of course in putting a Dem in the White House) will render the rantings about activism and 'beliefs' to be only so much blather. The Big Fat Liar in Chief said it during the Alito confirmation process--win an election or STFU. Knock the process all you want, but the GOP pizzed off enough Americans this past 6 years that they have pretty well shut themselves out of any opportunity to even obstruct any Obama judicial appointment. From the level of discourse I see lately, get used to it. title: Has the GOP Snuffed the Hispanic Vote for Good?

content: quote: Originally posted by Azurerepublic: You can only kiss the hispanic vote good bye if all hispanics are the same. But the racist hispanic vote, yeah, the GOP might be losing that vote. No one is saying that all Hispanics are the same. What some of us are simply saying is the GOP is losing Hispanic support which translates into votes. We saw that in the 2006 and 2008 elections. If those trends continue, and there is no reason to think that they won't, more Hispanics will be voting Democratic. I wouldn't go so far as to say that the GOP has lost 99% of the Hispanic vote, but that party has certainly lost over 50% of the Hispanic vote. When the GOP hate mongers such as Limbaugh and his likes make RACIST statements on radio/internet, constantly bashing President Obama, and Judge Sotomayer, it's not just Democrats who take notice of the negativism that is spewed. No one starts a war--or rather, no one in his senses ought to do so--without first being clear in his mind what he intends to achieve by that war and how he intends to conduct it. Carl von Clausewitz
quote: Originally posted by Azurerepublic: You can only kiss the hispanic vote good bye if all hispanics are the same. But the racist hispanic vote, yeah, the GOP might be losing that vote.
reply: No one is saying that all Hispanics are the same. What some of us are simply saying is the GOP is losing Hispanic support which translates into votes. We saw that in the 2006 and 2008 elections. If those trends continue, and there is no reason to think that they won't, more Hispanics will be voting Democratic. I wouldn't go so far as to say that the GOP has lost 99% of the Hispanic vote, but that party has certainly lost over 50% of the Hispanic vote. When the GOP hate mongers such as Limbaugh and his likes make RACIST statements on radio/internet, constantly bashing President Obama, and Judge Sotomayer, it's not just Democrats who take notice of the negativism that is spewed. No one starts a war--or rather, no one in his senses ought to do so--without first being clear in his mind what he intends to achieve by that war and how he intends to conduct it. Carl von Clausewitz
title: Has the GOP Snuffed the Hispanic Vote for Good?

content: quote: Originally posted by Yooper_tj: quote: Originally posted by ProgMod: quote: Originally posted by Azurerepublic: You can only kiss the hispanic vote good bye if all hispanics are the same. But the racist hispanic vote, yeah, the GOP might be losing that vote. No one is saying that all Hispanics are the same. What some of us are simply saying is the GOP is losing Hispanic support which translates into votes. We saw that in the 2006 and 2008 elections. If those trends continue, and there is no reason to think that they won't, more Hispanics will be voting Democratic. I wouldn't go so far as to say that the GOP has lost 99% of the Hispanic vote, but that party has certainly lost over 50% of the Hispanic vote. When the GOP hate mongers such as Limbaugh and his likes make RACIST statements on radio/internet, constantly bashing President Obama, and Judge Sotomayer, it's not just Democrats who take notice of the negativism that is spewed. ...and if this is truly a center-right country, that observation explains a great deal about the results of the last two congressional elections. Funny how the conservative purists ignore the most important equation I can imagine to their bottom line: Number of Conservative/Repubs in Congress minus the number of Liberal/Dems in Congress equals the net effect on the personal wealth of said conservative. More dems than repubs provides a negative solution to this equation. Shunning impure voters simply makes the negative larger in the next election. I always knew those guys weren't that good at math. Well, Conservative Purists are ignoring A LOT OF THINGS these days....... IMHO, they will simply continue this trend. Tea parties with crumpets and signs displaying Mr. Obama as a nazi or communist will not help their cause, indeed, it will only exacerbate GOP ills. This is especially true when Tom Tancredo and his kind, use the KKK analogy. I see absolutely no reason for repubs to slow or stop these tactics, when especially their red neck base not only applauds them, but like wild animals in the Roman Colosseum, they shout for more, and more, and more. No one starts a war--or rather, no one in his senses ought to do so--without first being clear in his mind what he intends to achieve by that war and how he intends to conduct it. Carl von Clausewitz

More dems than repubs provides a negative solution to this equation. Shunning impure voters simply makes the negative larger in the next election. I always knew those guys weren't that good at math.
